title: 108_s1732
content:
The Reclamation Rural Water Supply Act of 2003 may be cited as "The Reclamation Rural Water Supply Act of 2003". Definitions are provided in the Act. The Reclamation Rural Water Supply Act of 2003 defines key terms such as "construct" as installing new infrastructure or upgrading existing facilities, "Indian tribe" as a recognized entity eligible for federal services, and "non-federal project entity" as a state, regional, or local authority. The Reclamation Rural Water Supply Act of 2003 defines key terms such as "project entity" as a State, regional, or local authority, Indian tribe, or other qualifying entity, and "program" as the rural water supply program established under section 3(a). The term "project" refers to a water supply project for communities, Indian tribes, or dispersed homesites with domestic or rural water, including incidental livestock watering. The Act also defines "Reclamation law" as the Act of June 17, 1902 and Acts supplemental to and amendatory of that Act. The Reclamation Rural Water Supply Act of 2003 defines key terms such as "project entity" and "program." It also clarifies terms like "project" and "Reclamation law." The Act identifies a "Reclamation State" and the role of the "Secretary" in its implementation. The Reclamation Rural Water Supply Act of 2003 defines key terms and clarifies terms related to projects and Reclamation law. It also establishes a Rural Water Supply Program. The Secretary, with non-Federal entities, may implement a rural water supply program in Reclamation States. Eligibility criteria, including serving rural areas, Indian tribes, and addressing urgent water quality needs, will be developed and published for project assistance. The Secretary may implement a rural water supply program in Reclamation States with eligibility criteria focusing on serving rural areas, Indian tribes, addressing urgent water quality needs, and promoting regional water resource management. The cost-sharing requirement for federal projects involves the federal share being determined by the Secretary in the feasibility report, with a non-federal share of at least 25 percent but not exceeding the amount set in the report. The Secretary may reduce the non-Federal share of project costs if it causes economic hardship for the non-Federal entity, and grants from other Federal sources cannot be used to meet the non-Federal share requirement. SEC. 4. APPRAISAL INVESTIGATIONS.

The Secretary, in cooperation with non-Federal project entities and relevant authorities, may conduct an appraisal investigation to determine project eligibility for a feasibility study. A report with recommendations will be prepared, and the Secretary will cover the costs.

SEC. 5. FEASIBILITY STUDIES. The Secretary, with a non-Federal project entity, may conduct feasibility studies for rural water supply systems. Factors considered include project necessity, water demand and supplies, resource capability for safe water provision, and alternative solutions. The Secretary conducts feasibility studies for rural water supply systems with a non-Federal project entity. Factors considered include project necessity, water demand, resource capability, alternative solutions, economic feasibility, environmental impacts, water conservation measures, and financial ability of the non-Federal entity to pay for costs. Upon completion, a report is prepared describing engineering, environmental aspects. The Secretary conducts feasibility studies for rural water supply systems with a non-Federal project entity, considering project necessity, water demand, resource capability, economic feasibility, environmental impacts, water conservation measures, and financial ability. The report describes engineering, environmental, and economic activities, including a schedule for operation, maintenance, and replacement costs allocation. The Secretary conducts feasibility studies for rural water supply systems with a non-Federal project entity, considering project necessity, water demand, resource capability, economic feasibility, environmental impacts, water conservation measures, and financial ability. The report includes details on operation, maintenance, and replacement costs allocation. The Secretary submits recommendations to Congress for projects that should be carried out under this Act. The Secretary submits feasibility and environmental reports, along with a request for project development to Congress. Priorities for projects are based on economic incentives, cost benefits, fiscal controls, and partnerships. The Federal share of feasibility study costs under this program is limited to 50%, with the non-Federal share allowed in the form of in-kind services. If a project is constructed, the Federal share of feasibility studies will be considered project costs and reimbursed according to Reclamation law. SEC. 6. OPERATION, MAINTENANCE, AND REPLACEMENT COSTS. Non-Federal project entity must prove ability to cover all project costs. Develop plan with Secretary for cost framework. SEC. 7. MISCELLANEOUS PROVISIONS. SEC. 7. MISCELLANEOUS PROVISIONS. The Secretary has the authority to enter contracts and agreements to implement the Act. Funds for rural water supply projects cannot be used for irrigation facilities. Title to project components will be held by non-Federal entities. SEC. 8. EFFECT ON FEDERAL RECLAMATION LAW. This Act does not override Reclamation law or associated Federal laws. SEC. 9. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. Authorization of Appropriations: $70,000,000 is authorized annually for the implementation of the Act. Construction costs for projects will include necessary sums to cover cost increases due to inflation, with cost sharing based on allocation determined under section 3(c).
